title: About the Project
text:
“The true measure of any society can be found in how it treats its most vulnerable.”
— Mahatma Gandhi

311 is a city’s promise to listen. A pothole, a broken light, an abandoned sofa — each call is a signal. A test. A measure of trust.
San Francisco’s 311 hotline, like those in most major cities, was built to respond to everyday problems. But when half a million service requests are logged, patterns emerge — and so do disparities.
This project explores the stories hiding in that data: who gets help, how fast, and why.



Every dot in our data represents a resident’s voice — and a test of government responsiveness.







We began with four core questions:






Tip



1. What drives the number of requests submitted in different neighborhoods?
2. What influences how quickly or reliably a case is resolved?
3. Does photo evidence increase the likelihood or speed of resolution?
4. Are there disparities based on race, income, or geography?


We also explored time trends, disparities by case type, and resolution variation across neighborhoods.






We analyzed over 519,000 records of 311 service requests filed in San Francisco during 2012, 2014, 2016, and 2018. Each record includes:

Case type and submission method

Whether a photo was attached

Time to resolution and resolution status

Neighborhood location and timestamp

Neighborhood-level demographics: race, income, turnout

These were cleaned and transformed using Python and R, joined with census data and spatial overlays, and structured for statistical analysis and storytelling.



Income and race strongly correlate with resolution rates — but correlation isn’t causation.









  
    
      
      
        Example: Pothole Request
      
    
    
      
      
        Impact of Photo Evidence on Resolution
      
    
    
      
      
        Most Frequent Case Types
      
    
  
  
    
    Previous
  
  
    
    Next
  



<img src="assets/images/pothole_example.jpg" alt="Pothole case">
<p class="image-caption">Example: Pothole Request (JavaScript disabled - carousel not available)</p>








The 311 system is designed for accessibility and equity. But our analysis reveals:






Key Findings




Some neighborhoods receive quicker and more consistent service

Photo evidence significantly increases resolution likelihood

Race, income, and civic turnout correlate with resolution patterns




These gaps — while subtle — matter. Because a small delay for one neighborhood might mean chronic neglect for another.



Even frequent complaints aren’t treated equally across the city.








This dashboard is built for:






Note




Residents who want to know how their neighborhood compares

City officials seeking fairer resource allocation

Civic tech advocates promoting transparency

Researchers and data scientists interested in applied policy analysis



Whether you’re a policy student, data enthusiast, or simply a curious citizen — we invite you to explore.






Want to dive deeper into the modeling details, statistical tests, and regression coefficients?

  Download the full paper (PDF) 





“Data doesn’t change the world. Stories do — especially when the data is honest, and the stories are true.”

Let us know if you’d like to reuse this work or bring it to your city.
The code is modular, the questions are transferable — and the insights can empower communities far beyond San Francisco.

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
“Cities speak through their systems.”
This dashboard listens closely to what San Francisco’s 311 requests reveal — about equity, efficiency, and responsiveness.

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
Resolution Rates by Neighborhood
This interactive map visualizes how well each neighborhood’s requests are resolved. Try toggling between requests with and without photo evidence to see the impact.

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
The Power of Photo Evidence
Cases with photos are resolved nearly 30% faster on average. This bar chart makes the difference clear:



Download interactive chart as HTML

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
Which Case Types Get Resolved?
Some services are handled efficiently; others fall through the cracks. This chart ranks the top 10 case types by resolution rate.



Download interactive chart as HTML

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
Income Disparities Across Neighborhoods
Hover over this dot map to see average income by neighborhood. How does income relate to resolution speed?



Download interactive chart as HTML

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
Income Distribution: Choropleth Map
A broader look at geographic inequality in income levels:



Download map as HTML

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
section: Subset Selection: The Most Predictive Features
text:
Subset Selection: The Most Predictive Features
Using R² and BIC, we identify the most impactful predictors of resolution success.



Download interactive chart as HTML

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
Key Takeaways


Photo evidence speeds up service.


Resolution rates are uneven across income and racial lines.


Case type matters — some requests are much more likely to be resolved.

title: 311 Hotline Resolution Explorer
text:
Why This Matters
Municipal data isn’t just numbers. It’s a record of who gets served, and who doesn’t. In a city striving for equity, these patterns must be visible — so they can be challenged and changed.

title: Data Visualization Gallery
text:
Explore Key Visual Insights
Each visualization offers a window into a specific facet of service delivery — from racial disparity to resolution timing and neighborhood inequalities. Filter below to focus on what interests you.

All Bar: Horizontal Bar: Vertical Line Charts Heatmaps Ranked Tables






× 
















 Back to top

title: Methods
text:
We approached this project as storytellers, not just statisticians. Our goal wasn’t just to model numbers — it was to uncover patterns of equity and inequality in the delivery of public services. Here’s how we did it.



Every data point begins with a real request, like this pothole report from SF 311.







We started by letting the data speak.

How often are cases opened in each neighborhood?
Are certain types resolved more reliably?
Does submitting a photo really help?

We used bar charts, dot maps, and choropleths to bring these questions to life.



Case type matters: Some requests are always resolved. Others? Almost never.








Visuals gave us clues. Statistics gave us confidence.



Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test → Confirmed: Photo submissions lead to faster resolutions (p < 0.001)


Chi-Squared Test → Confirmed: Photo presence significantly associated with resolution success


We also observed race-based differences that demanded closer modeling attention.






We needed to go deeper.



Negative Binomial Regression



Modeled counts of cases per neighborhood


Controlled for overdispersion


Revealed: Case type, income, and demographics significantly affect service likelihood



Ridge & Lasso Regression



Modeled resolution rates


Addressed multicollinearity in demographic predictors


Lasso shrank complexity, Ridge gave robustness






Income and race correlate strongly with resolution rates — but correlation isn’t causation.








We tested dozens of combinations to balance complexity and explanatory power.











Download interactive chart as HTML







Place matters.



Dot Map - Shows income per neighborhood at its centroid













Download interactive map as HTML




Choropleth - Visualizes income inequality across geographic boundaries





Download map as HTML







Data alone isn’t enough — it must engage.



D3 Resolution Map


An interactive map powered by D3.js lets users:



Hover to see neighborhood data


Toggle by photo evidence


Reveal hotspots of inefficiency



📁 Source: js/resolution_map.js


Visualization Gallery


Like a visual journal, our gallery uses JavaScript + JSON to filter and zoom through our EDA snapshots.


📁 Code: js/gallery.js


📁 Data: data/data_gallery_info.json


📁 Images: assets/images/static_viz/


Interactive Quiz


We built a custom JavaScript quiz that:



Randomly picks 3 questions per attempt


Celebrates correct answers with confetti 🎉


Offers supportive feedback and replay



📁 File: quiz.qmd


🎉 Library: canvas-confetti








We stitched this project together with care — and code:




Languages: Python + R + JavaScript


Python: Altair, Pandas, Folium, GeoPandas, SciPy, Statsmodels


R: glmnet, MASS, ggplot2


JS: D3.js, plain DOM scripting






Scan to access the live dashboard and explore the story yourself.
